properties.name: SMTP Target Name
properties.description: The name of the SMTP target you want to use when sending outgoing mail

properties.name: Notification Email Addresses
properties.description: List of email addresses to send investigation notifications to. The email addresses should either be comma separated or each on their own line

properties.name: Ticket Text
properties.description: Placeholder used throughout the workflow to compile information for SecureX casebooks and incidents. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Observables Table
properties.description: A table containing observables found during the investigation. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Consolidated Headers
properties.description: Placeholder uses to compile a list of email headers. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Number of Threat Grid Submissions
properties.description: How many files and URLs were submitted to Threat Grid for analysis during the investigation. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Phish Sender
properties.description: The sender of the email that was submitted for investigation. This is something we attempt to extract from the attachment headers and will be populated automatically

properties.name: Webex Teams Room Name
properties.description: The name of the Webex Teams room to post messages to. If using a bot, make sure to invite your bot to the room before attempting to send messages. If you don't want to use Webex, leave this blank

properties.name: Number of Unknown Observables
properties.description: How many observables the investigation found with a Unknown disposition. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Has Email Attachment
properties.description: Whether or not the email sent for investigation has an email attached to it. Since we want users to forward the suspicious email as an attachment, we check to make sure this is true after the attachments are processed

properties.name: Threat Response Environment URL
properties.description: Placeholder for the URL of the Threat Response environment being used. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Threat Response Access Token
properties.description: Placeholder for the Threat Response access token. This token will be fetched as needed throughout the workflow and this variable should not be modified

properties.name: Number of Clean Observables
properties.description: How many observables the investigation found with a Clean disposition. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Phish Recipients
properties.description: The recipients of the email that was submitted for investigation. This is something we attempt to extract from the attachment headers and will be populated automatically

properties.name: SecureX Environment URL
properties.description: Placeholder for the URL of the SecureX environment being used. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Secure Malware Analytics Environment URL
properties.description: Placeholder for the URL of the Secure Malware Analytics environment being used. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Observables JSON
properties.description: Placeholder used to build a JSON list of observables found during the investigation. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Threat Response Token Time
properties.description: The time at which the Threat Response access token was last fetched. This is used to determine when it's time to fetch a new token and should not be modified

properties.name: Phish Subject
properties.description: The subject of the email that was submitted for investigation. This is something we attempt to extract from the attachment headers and will be populated automatically

properties.name: Number of Suspicious Observables
properties.description: How many observables the investigation found with a Suspicious disposition. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Webex Teams Access Token
properties.description: The access token to use to authenticate to the Webex Teams API. Information about using a bot, which is what we recommend, can be found here: https://developer.webex.com/docs/bots

properties.name: Number of Malicious Observables
properties.description: How many observables the investigation found with a Malicious disposition. This will be populated automatically

properties.name: Secure Malware Analytics API Key
properties.description: The API key to use with Secure Malware Analytics. You can either set this here (and remove this variable from the Fetch Global Variables activity) or you can use the Fetch Global Variables activity to update this variable with an existing API key from a global variable

properties.name: Secure Malware Analytics Threat Score
properties.description: Placeholder for the threat score for URLs/files being analyzed by Secure Malware Analytics. This will be populated automatically

This workflow monitors a mailbox for incoming phishing reports. When an email is received, the workflow investigates its attachments and attempts to determine if anything in the email (or its attachments) was suspicious or malicious. If anything suspicious or malicious is found, the user is told to delete the email, a casebook and incident are created in Cisco SecureX, a Webex Teams message is posted, and an email is sent to a "SOC" email address.

Target Group: Default TargetGroup

Targets: CTR_API, CTR_For_Access_Token, Phishing Investigation Mailbox, Phishing Investigation Outgoing, Private_CTIA_Target, ThreatGrid_Target, Webex Teams

More information: https://ciscosecurity.github.io/sxo-05-security-workflows/workflows/0010

Hello!

The email you submitted for review with the subject "$trigger.triggerevent_01LDICT231ZS43miaxKIy0SEERAAMo7ddn6.output.subject$" is being processed.

While we investigate, please do not open or share the message. Once we determine whether or not the email is safe, we will get back to you.

Please re-submit the suspicious email by forwarding it as an attachment or, if available, by using the "Report Suspicious Email" button in your email client.

actions.name: Execute Python Script
actions.title: Execute GET request to the URL

properties.display_name: Execute GET request to the URL
properties.script:
import sys,requests,re

# Get the URL to request
testUrl = sys.argv[1]

# Make sure there's no trailing HTML
if testUrl.find("<") >= 0:
	testUrl = testUrl[0:testUrl.find("<")]

# Request the content of the URL
urlRequest = requests.get(testUrl, headers={ 'User-Agent': 'Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/41.0.2228.0 Safari/537.3' }, allow_redirects=False)

# Check if the response was a redirect
statusCode = urlRequest.status_code
redirected = False
if statusCode in [301, 302, 303, 307, 308]:
	redirected = True

if matches:
	fileSupported = True

actions.name: Condition Block
actions.title: Was there anything suspicious or malicious?

properties.display_name: Was there anything suspicious or malicious?

actions.name: Group
actions.title: Truncate the ticket text if needed

properties.display_name: Truncate the ticket text if needed

properties.script:
import sys

# Placeholder for the output text
trimmedText = ""

# Check if we need to truncate
if len(sys.argv[1]) <= 4200:
	trimmedText = sys.argv[1]
else:
	# Loop through each line of input
	for line in sys.argv[1].split("\n"):
		# Is the message too long?
		if len(trimmedText) > 4200:
			# Yes, so add a warning and stop the look
			trimmedText = trimmedText + "\nNOTE: Additional investigation information was truncated due to message length limits"
			break
		else:
			# No, so keep appending
			trimmedText = trimmedText + "\n" + line

import sys, json

existingObservables = json.loads(sys.argv[1])
observableType = sys.argv[2]
observableValue = sys.argv[3]

existingObservables.append({ "type": observableType, "value": observableValue })

observableJson = json.dumps(existingObservables)
